results.title: Acids, bases and salts. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Mel Waskin, Roger Mazur and Coronet Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemistry”.
Differing in their reaction with indicators, acids can be defined as proton acceptors using the Bronsted-Lowry theory. The Lewis theory is also explained, as well as the meaning of pH.

results.title: Solutions: ionic and molecular. - 2nd ed.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemistry”.
Illustrates the chemical nature of a solution, what happens when it forms and the role of the electrostatic forces. Shows Brownian movement, defines saturation and presents the concept of molarity along with an explanation of why some substances, eg oil, won’t dissolve in other substances such as water. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Chemical bonding and atomic structure. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Mel Waskin, Roger Mazur, Coronet Films and Don Lane Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemistry”.
The substances forming our world are composed of atoms held together by powerful electrical forces called chemical bonds. The physical and chemical properties of elements and compounds depend on the nature of these bonds. Discusses metallic, ionic, covalent and interatomic bonds and forces dealing with ions, atoms, crystals, valence, polarity and Van der Waals forces. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Chemical bond and atomic structure
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemistry”.
Discusses the structure of the atom and shows how the electrons help determine the way in which the atom bonds chemically with other atoms. Shows three types of chemical bonding and explains how bonding affects substance. (Suitable for years 11-12)

results.title: Bromine - Element from the sea
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Experiments show the great reactivity of bromine with metals and non-metals, giving products readily soluble in water. A procedure is developed for the extraction of bromine from a dilute sodium bromide solution such as sea water.

results.title: Shapes and polarities of molecules
results.creator_credit: National Science Foundation and Norman Wright Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Observations of electrical effects lead to the concept of molecular polarity. Covalent substances give two types of results: some show marked interactions with electric charges, others give little effect. A model is developed based on polar and non-polar molecules. The molecular dipole model is extended to explain differences in solubility, conductivity and chemical reactivity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Science Foundation and Norman Wright Productions

results.title: Acid base indicators
results.creator_credit: David W. Ridgway, University of California, Los Angeles and Wexler Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Proton donor-acceptor theory is used to interpret the experimental behaviour of acid-base indicators. Experiments and animation show the effects on indicators of changing acidity. Equilibrium constants of four indicators are determined and the indicators arranged in order of decreasing acid strength. The competition among bases for protons is shown by mixing the indicators and showing that each changes colour at different total acidity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David W. Ridgway, University of California, Los Angeles and Wexler Film Productions
